We investigate how the Fourier transform of \\( z(t) \\), defined as \\( Z(\\omega) = \\mathcal{F}\\{z(t)\\} \\), impacts causal inference.

Since the Fourier transform is linear but sensitive to input, \\( Z(\\omega) \\) will capture these differences, especially given the dependency on A, B, C, and D.
